title: 103_hr2632
content: The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes appropriations of $103,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 to the Patent and Trademark Office. Fees collected under title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946 will also be made available to the office. Amounts appropriated under this Act may remain available until expended. Adjustments to trademark fees are also authorized. SEC. 4. ADJUSTMENT OF TRADEMARK FEES. The fee for filing a trademark registration application will be $245 as of the enactment date of this Act, with any fee adjustments not taking effect before October 1, 1994. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to allow for an interim extension of a patent term if the regulatory review period for the product covered by the patent extends beyond the expiration of the patent term. The owner or agent of the patent can submit an application for an interim extension 6 months before the term expires, providing specific information about the product and patent. The owner or agent of a patent can apply for an interim extension if the regulatory review period for the product covered by the patent extends beyond its expiration. The application must include details such as the patent identity, claims related to the product, activities undertaken during the review period, and any additional information required by the Commissioner. If the patent is deemed eligible for an extension, a notice will be published in the Federal Register, and a certificate of interim extension will be issued for up to 1 year. The owner of a patent can apply for an interim extension if the regulatory review period extends beyond the patent's expiration. Up to 4 subsequent interim extensions can be applied for, with specific application timelines. Each extension is recorded in the patent file and considered part of the original patent. The extension terminates 60 days after commercial marketing permission, unless the Commissioner is notified within that period. The Commissioner may grant further extension of a patent for up to 5 years from the original expiration date if additional information is provided. Rights during the extension period are limited to uses under regulatory review. SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, including changes to subsections (a), (b), and (e). SEC. 7. PATENT TERM EXTENSIONS FOR AMERICAN LEGION. SEC. 7. Patent term extensions for American Legion: Design patents for the badges of the American Legion, American Legion Women's Auxiliary, and Sons of the American Legion are renewed and extended for 14 years from the date of enactment. SEC. 8. INTERVENING RIGHTS. The renewals and extensions of patents under section 6 will not infringe on any patent for use that began after expiration but before the enactment of this Act.
